repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Irrigation Based Community
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation Based
            Community Development (IBCD) Project for Morocco were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory.  Some lessons learned included: the
            project demonstrated that participatory community-based
            planning and integrated local level investment programming
            anchored in Small and Medium Scale Irrigation (SMI) are
            feasible in rural areas of Morocco and add value in terms
            both of appropriation by the beneficiaries and of
            development impact. In fact, SMI proved the optimal entry
            point for integrated development in mountain areas as all
            social and economic life in these zones is organized around
            the irrigation perimeter. The project also demonstrated that
            Government agencies are both able and willing to implement
            this approach, and that fiscal decentralization, the Rural
            Development Fund (FDR) under the management of the Governor,
            aids the approach. The lesson is that the IBCD model is an
            effective mechanism for reducing rural poverty and the
            project model is ready, subject to some adjustments, to be
            extended to other areas and scaled up. A related lesson is
            that a project such as the IBCD project, introduced to
            pioneer the implementation of a new strategy, should not
            only invest in Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) from the
            outset so as to provide empirical evidence of results but
            also have an inbuilt communications program to ensure that
            emerging messages are passed to decision makers and other
            key stakeholders, and so are fed back into the policy,
            strategy, and programming cycle.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Irrigation Based Community
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The first phase of the Irrigation Based
            Community Development (IBCD) Project will seek to improve
            the incomes and quality of life of rural communities
            centered on small and medium irrigation (SMI) in 15
            provinces over a 13-year period, primarily through
            demand-driven, coordinated investments in SMI rehabilitation
            and improvement and complementary community infrastructure,
            including rural roads, water supply/sanitation,
            electrification, health, and education facilities. The
            first-phased project consists of the following components:
            The first component supports rehabilitation of SMI serving
            an area of approximately 9,450 hectares (ha), of which 3,450
            ha in Azilal and an estimated 3,000 ha each in Khenifra and
            Al Haouz. The second component will support complementary
            community infrastructure not covered by ongoing sectoral
            programs. The third component will support institutional
            strengthening through a training and technical assistance
            program for agricultural development activities to intensify
            production practices and thereby increase farmers'
            income. The last component will support the preparation of
            the next phase of the project through participatory,
            integrated programming of the IBCD activities in six
            additional provinces to be selected.

Morocco - Irrigation Based Community

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Irrigation-Based Community
            Development Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Irrigation Based Community
            Development Project will rehabilitate agricultural land in
            fifteen provinces for small, and medium size irrigation, and
            for integrated rural development, through improved
            infrastructure, and agricultural development measures. While
            positive impacts such as reduction of water losses, improved
            flood protection, and reduced incidence of water borne
            diseases as a result of better access to clean water, are
            expected, negative impacts will occur. These refer to
            potential, increased agro-chemical pollution; ecological
            impacts due to increased water diversion affecting wetlands,
            and other types of non-agricultural vegetation; potential
            uses of irrigation canals for non-agricultural water supply,
            or as a sewer in rural settlements; potential erosion caused
            by road construction; uncontrolled waste disposal; and, risk
            of groundwater resources exploitation. The impacts will be
            mitigated by the following measures: 1) extension, and
            training on irrigation performance management, and sound
            fertilizer application will be integrated under technical
            assistance components; 2) ecological impacts due to
            increased water diversion will undergo monitoring on
            vegetative practices; 3) water discharge measurement points
            will be constructed, to monitor better maintenance, and
            cleaning of irrigation flows; 4) drainage measures, and
            soil/water conservation practices will control water quality
            as per technical guidelines; and, 5) groundwater/aquifer
            capacity will be assessed ex-ante, and effective pumping
            will control water quantities.
